ResearchProjectDef.label: Glyph deciphering
ResearchProjectDef.description: The symbols etched into Dwarfgates—and scribbled across ominous scrolls—aren’t just artistic flair. Decoding them may unlock a galaxy-spanning transit network. Or a death trap. Possibly both.
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterText:
Your researchers have cracked the code behind the glyphs adorning the Dwarfgate.

These symbols are more than mere decoration; they represent coordinates and commands essential for operating the gate network.

With this newfound knowledge, your colony can now begin to unlock the secrets of gate travel.

Caution is advised: some glyphs may lead to destinations best left unexplored.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Refine Naquadah
ResearchProjectDef.description:
Learn to stabilize and refine raw Naquadah into Naquadria — a hyperreactive isotope capable of powering anything from handheld energy weapons to planetary-scale disasters.

The process is equal parts chemistry, theoretical physics, and prayer.

One misplaced decimal and you’ll discover a new crater where your lab used to be — but hey, progress has casualties.
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterText:
Your researchers have done the unthinkable: refined Naquadah into its unstable cousin, Naquadria.

It produces enough energy to power a city—or erase one. Testing reports describe the reaction as “beautiful” right before the shielding melted.

Theoretical containment procedures are now logged. Whether they’ll hold is another matter.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Ancient alloys
ResearchProjectDef.description: By combining Plasteel, Uranium, Naquadah, and Steel, our scientists have created an absurdly strong, absurdly unstable alloy.\nToo volatile for furniture, perfect for high-stakes wormhole shielding.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Irises
ResearchProjectDef.description: By placing an ultra-thin barrier mere microns from a Dwarfgate's event horizon, we can prevent reintegration of inbound matter.\nIn simpler terms: unwanted guests go *splat*. Handy.

ResearchProjectDef.label: DHD logic
ResearchProjectDef.description: By studying salvaged Dwarfgate alloys and Tau'ri fabrication techniques, researchers have developed a way to create a more... replaceable DHD.\nIt won’t impress the Ancients, but it dials just fine.
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterText:
Through painstaking analysis — and at least one accidental power surge — your researchers have created a Tau’ri replacement for the ancient Dwarfgate dialer.

It’s not elegant, but it *works*: no line-of-sight needed, extended range, and full remote control of the gate’s iris. A triumph of modern engineering and excessive coffee consumption.

Just don’t unplug it — the hum means it’s working.

Note: Your researchers also believe they can train field members how to salvage destroyed DHDs and hijack a direct gate interface link that will allow dialing out in case of emergency.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Replicator link
ResearchProjectDef.description: Salvaged from fallen Replicators, this inert link module hums faintly with dormant nanite activity.\n\nBy studying its structure and field patterns, we may unlock new ways to combat—or perhaps even control—these relentless machines.
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterText:
Analysis of the inert Replicator link has yielded partial schematics and a long list of unanswered questions.

Your team believes the bonding field patterns can be reverse-engineered to disrupt active swarms—or even repurpose dormant nanites for friendly use.

As one researcher put it: “If we can make them stop… maybe we can make them help.”

ResearchProjectDef.label: Replicator gestation
ResearchProjectDef.description:
By synthesizing Replicator link modules with advanced mechanoid fabrication techniques, we can initiate controlled gestation of Replicator units.

This process is delicate: too little energy and the nanites fail to cohere; too much, and you risk unleashing a hostile swarm.

With careful monitoring, however, we can produce Replicators for study—or even defense.

Caution is advised: their intelligence approaches that of sentient beings, raising ethical considerations alongside practical ones.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Anti-Replicator
ResearchProjectDef.description:
A classified Tau’ri prototype adapted for field use: a directed energy pulse tuned to scramble Replicator bonding fields.

To organics it’s underwhelming; to Replicators it’s an existential crisis.

Production is slow, maintenance is grumpy, and the safety brief is just the word “Don’t” written six times.
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterText:
Analysis of the inert Replicator link has yielded a usable emission profile.

Your team believes a tuned pulse can disrupt nanite cohesion long enough to turn active swarms into quiet scrap.

Field note #1: the pulse makes nearby Replicator debris tingle in a way that is deeply upsetting.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Puddle Jumper
ResearchProjectDef.description:
Blueprints recovered from the remains of an Ancient “Puddle Jumper” — a sleek, self-sealing scout craft built for silent insertion and questionable bravery.

While the Ancients designed it for interstellar gates, the Tau’ri (and now, us) have re-engineered it for local atmospheric and orbital hops.

No wormhole travel, no auto-navigation, and definitely no manual that anyone can read — but it flies, shields, and occasionally terrifies pilots into sainthood.
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterText:
Analysis of the ruined Ancient scout craft has yielded partial schematics and a long list of unanswered questions.

Your team believes the design can be replicated — minus the exotic drive core and wormhole-rated frame. The resulting model should perform admirably in-atmosphere and for short-range exo flights.

As one researcher put it: “If it hums like that when powered, it’s either stable… or alive.”

ResearchProjectDef.label: ZPM core
ResearchProjectDef.description: Decode Ancient supervisory fields and safety interlocks to bind a ZPM into modern distributions without catastrophic feedback. Until this is understood, a ZPM will remain inert when connected.
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterText:
When your scientists finally cracked the containment lattice schematics, the lab went silent.

Every reading, every oscillation, every micro-field pointed to one conclusion: this was no ordinary crystal lattice. The ZPM’s inner structure is a sealed universe—an engineered pocket of subspace siphoning the quantum foam itself.

Your researchers now understand the basic interlocks required to awaken such a device without annihilating half the map.
Once integrated into a power grid, a ZPM will initialize and begin harnessing and storing energy on a scale previously thought impossible.

Be warned: this brilliance does not go unnoticed. The moment the containment field hums to life, eyes will turn toward your colony.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Subspace masking
ResearchProjectDef.description: Reverse-engineer Ancient carrier-noise and Tau’ri signal hygiene to hide a ZPM’s telltale subspace bleed. Not true invisibility—just enough distortion to keep opportunists from triangulating your base every other day.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Subspace coupling
ResearchProjectDef.description: Exploit cross-brane phase offsets to alternate a ZPM’s vacuum tap between adjacent subspace pockets. This doesn’t “refill” a ZPM so much as rotate where it drinks from. The math is ugly; the hum is beautiful.
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterText: By expressing vacuum fluctuations across parallel subspace branes, your engineers can “phase-hop” a ZPM’s intake. Connected ZPMs will now gradually replenish reserves while a diverter runs on the same power net. Don’t stare at the interference fringes too long.

ResearchProjectDef.label: ZPM Housing
ResearchProjectDef.description: Reconstruct Ancient multi-module containment architecture to safely align the output of multiple ZPMs. The original schematics assume access to a city-sized power grid, a few dozen drones, and a civilization that didn’t routinely store dead rats and beer in their workbenches.\n\nWith enough reverse-engineering, your colony can fabricate a compact cradle capable of synchronizing multiple ZPMs without blowing a hole in the local spacetime topology.
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterText:
When the final glyph-lock snapped into place, your researchers didn’t cheer—they just stepped back, very slowly, as the holographic interface resolved itself into something unmistakably… Ancient.

The device before them isn’t just a docking frame. It’s a harmonizer, a stabilizer, and a very polite suggestion to the universe that several sealed micro-cosms should all pretend to act like one big battery.

Through careful reconstruction (and one memorable incident with a lab bench now permanently fused to the ceiling), your team decoded how the Ancients balanced parallel zero-point feeds.

With a proper containment housing, multiple ZPMs can now be aligned, synchronized, and—gods help you—combined.

Just remember: the Ancients built these things under strict conditions, not next to a wooden barracks full of hungry boomrats.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Shield Emitter
ResearchProjectDef.description: Ancient notes describe a way to interweave hyper-activated quantum fields to create a defensive barrier around your base. With the help of a ZPM housing, it's actually feasible to power such a device on a large enough scale to protect against incoming attacks and provide a safe haven for your colonists.
